title: Impact of the Eurékoi Serious Game on Family Caregivers of Patients With a Major Neurocognitive Disorder
description_brief: This study aims to assess the effectiveness of serious EUREKOI gambling on the anxiety of family caregivers of patients with newly diagnosed Alzheimer's disease.
explanation_target: Reason: The described trial tests the Eurékoi "serious game" delivered to family caregivers to reduce their anxiety — a behavioral/nonpharmacological, caregiver-focused intervention rather than a drug, biologic, or a patient-targeted cognitive/neuropsychiatric treatment. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Act: I searched clinical-trial registries and trial listings and found the study registered as NCT04573985 (Impact of the Eurékoi Serious Game on Family Caregivers of Patients With a Major Neurocognitive Disorder) run by CHU de Nice; it lists the intervention as a 1-session group "serious game Eurekoi" with anxiety (Spielberger inventory) as the primary outcome and is classified as a behavioral intervention (Completed). citeturn0search0turn0search8

Reflect: Because the intervention is a serious game for caregivers (non-drug, non-biologic) and aims to reduce caregiver anxiety rather than modify Alzheimer pathology or directly improve patients' cognition/neuropsychiatric symptoms, it does not fit any of the four target categories (disease-targeted biologic, disease-targeted small molecule, cognitive enhancer, neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). Therefore the correct classification is 'N/A'. I also note that serious games are discussed in the literature as nonpharmacological interventions for cognition/behavior in AD/MCI, supporting that this is a behavioral (non-drug) approach. citeturn0search3
